dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh, you've gotta be kidding me. That whole trade war thing with China? I mean, really?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh, you've gotta be kidding me. That whole trade war thing with China? I mean, really?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it was, uh, quite a ride, wasn't it? Like, a real... mess, if we're being honest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it was, uh, quite a ride, wasn't it? Like, a real... mess, if we're being honest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, so Trump, he thought it would, like, totally cripple China, right? Make them stop competing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, so Trump, he thought it would, like, totally cripple China, right? Make them stop competing?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He seems to have assumed that his policies would harm China to the point that it could not effectively compete with the US economically, politically, or militarily.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, that was, um, the idea. Or, at least, what his advisors, some with, you know, questionable economic backgrounds, led him to believe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, that was, um, the idea. Or, at least, what his advisors, some with, you know, questionable economic backgrounds, led him to believe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Questionable? Like, what does that even mean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Questionable? Like, what does that even mean?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It means, uh, even internal Pentagon reports were saying China's economy was pretty much unstoppable, fueled by all this investment and tech. It was like shouting into the wind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It means, uh, even internal Pentagon reports were saying China's economy was pretty much unstoppable, fueled by all this investment and tech. It was like shouting into the wind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, he was trying to shrink them down, but also kinda talking to them privately? That's... confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, he was trying to shrink them down, but also kinda talking to them privately? That's... confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, at the same time that his administration was trying to diminish China, it was negotiating with it bilaterally, thereby sending a very confusing signal to the Chinese and the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Super conflicting signals to everyone. And while China did have some temporary setbacks, it actually hurt the US economy quite a bit, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Super conflicting signals to everyone. And while China did have some temporary setbacks, it actually hurt the U S economy quite a bit, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumpian policies no doubt damaged China, but they hurt the US, too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. So it backfired? But like, how did China even get so big in the first place? I thought they were, like, closed off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. So it backfired? But like, how did China even get so big in the first place? I thought they were, like, closed off.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure, back until the early eighties, their economy was really constrained. But then, uh, they made this huge shift, embraced private enterprise.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure, back until the early eighties, their economy was really constrained. But then, uh, they made this huge shift, embraced private enterprise.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until the early 1980s, China was very poor, and economic growth was anemic, because the government discouraged foreign trade and sought to produce all goods domestically, mostly in state enterprises. But the country then reversed its trade policies and allowed private enterprise.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Like, what, opened up to the world?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like, what, opened up to the world?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! And their trade, exports and imports, just surged. It was a massive engine for growth, totally transformed them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! And their trade, exports and imports, just surged. It was a massive engine for growth, totally transformed them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its opening to the world triggered a remarkable economic transformation. Exports and imports both grew quickly and became major growth engines, leading to rapidly rising living standards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then the WTO thing, right? I remember hearing about that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then the W T O thing, right? I remember hearing about that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, by the late nineties, everyone saw the benefit of them joining the World Trade Organization. It promised adherence to global rules, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, by the late nineties, everyone saw the benefit of them joining the World Trade Organization. It promised adherence to global rules, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By the 1990s, it was evident that both China and the global economy would benefit from Chinese accession to the WTO. Membership, many argued, would assure other countries that China would follow the global trade rules that had contributed much to strong global economic growth since World War II, while the WTO would provide a forum for resolving disputes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And did they? Like, actually follow the rules?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And did they? Like, actually follow the rules?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For the most part, yeah. They lowered tariffs, eliminated barriers. And the US, uh, actually won a lot of its cases against China at the WTO, especially on intellectual property.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For the most part, yeah. They lowered tariffs, eliminated barriers. And the U S, uh, actually won a lot of its cases against China at the W T O, especially on intellectual property.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Accordingly, China lowered its average tariff rate from 40% in 1992 to 15% by 2000 (and still further subsequently) and removed other trade barriers in order to conform to the WTOs rules, before joining the organization in 2001. The US took many of its trade grievances with China to the WTO, and won most of its cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, if we were winning, why did Trump just, like, blow it all up with tariffs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, if we were winning, why did Trump just, like, blow it all up with tariffs?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, his administration, um, didn't really use that WTO framework. He just issued these inflexible demands, like requiring them to buy way more US goods.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, his administration, um, didn't really use that W T O framework. He just issued these inflexible demands, like requiring them to buy way more U S goods.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After Trump took office, his administration attacked China and its trade policies without using WTO processes. He made nonnegotiable demands including that China close the bilateral trade deficit by importing vastly more US goods and dramatically increased US tariffs on imports from China in an attempt to get his way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that didn't work? Because I remember hearing about, like, soybeans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that didn't work? Because I remember hearing about, like, soybeans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right! Economists were saying the trade deficit was more about big picture macroeconomic stuff, not something tariffs would easily fix. And forcing them to buy specific things, thatâ€™s, uh, managed trade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Economists were saying the trade deficit was more about big picture macroeconomic stuff, not something tariffs would easily fix. And forcing them to buy specific things, that's, uh, managed trade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economists pointed out that the US trade deficit with China was a macroeconomic phenomenon and not something that could be reduced by tariffs. Moreover, forcing China to commit to import more US commodities such as soybeans would require managed trade, especially by Chinese state-owned enterprises whose behavior the Trump administration was complaining about.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh. So, it was just... a big failure, then? And now it's still, like, super hostile?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh. So, it was just... a big failure, then? And now it's still, like, super hostile?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His trade war was thus ultimately a failure that harmed both China and the US. Today, US-China trade relations are openly hostile, and America is by no means the innocent party.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much, yeah. Lasting negative consequences for both. But there is a way forward, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much, yeah. Lasting negative consequences for both. But there is a way forward, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh? How?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh? How?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Like, we could, uh, reinstate the WTO's dispute settlement. Get those Appellate Body judges approved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like, we could, uh, reinstate the W T O's dispute settlement. Get those Appellate Body judges approved.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But both countries could begin to reset relations with an agreement to restore the WTOs dispute-settlement role through US approval of new Appellate Body judges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, go back to what we were doing, but, like, better?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, go back to what we were doing, but, like, better?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and maybe Biden could even rescind Trump's tariffs if China, like, reciprocates. Focus on shared challenges, multilateral frameworks. That's, um, the smart path.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and maybe Biden could even rescind Trump's tariffs if China, like, reciprocates. Focus on shared challenges, multilateral frameworks. That's, um, the smart path.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration could make a further goodwill gesture by offering to rescind Trumps tariffs on condition that China reciprocates.
